text: hi everyone this is a yellow flannel
review but i'm too lazy to change my
shirt here it's nice and warm
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of this new
kralis album crystalline exhaustion this
is the newest full-length lp from new
york black metal outfit kralis one of
the longest running black metal acts out
of the u.s currently crowless hit just
as there was a sudden wave of interest
in atmospheric black metal in the u.s
which spread across the hipster in indie
blogs like wildfire in the late 2000s
though kralis's sound and style was
decidedly more progressive and technical
than many of their contemporaries at the
time and how could they not be with
avant-garde metal virtuosos colin
marston and mick barr writing so many of
the riffs and winding song structures in
these tracks at the time kralis had just
been one of many bands that mick and
colin nick mcmaster and lev weinstein
had been involved in but in a couple
short years it would become one of the
most epic and consequential groups
they'd ever start especially since the
release of years past matter which is
easily one of the fiercest and most
decimating american black metal records
of all time the thunderous mix searing
tremolo guitars and tight but fluid
drumming are just on another level and
the record still hits hard a decade
later now a lot of krali's core albums
since the release of this lp haven't
been nearly as robust though the band
did continue experimenting with
different production styles death metal
elements progressive elements
collaborations synthesizers too which
have led to some of the most interesting
moments on records like gobi forgotten
as well as demonic wealth which was kind
of the band's pandemic record it was
packed with some of their boldest and
most interesting ideas in a long time
but they did release it
with a decidedly imperfect mix the
instrumentation wasn't captured under
the most ideal circumstances either with
the drums being recorded on a phone and
the vocals said to be caught in a car
near a swamp thankfully crystalline
exhaustion doesn't have any of those
recording hang-ups or anything i should
also note there's a bit of a recording
gimmick on this record as i guess
everyone on this lp except lev
switched instruments in addition to that
it might just be kralis's biggest and
baddest record in years the thunderous
mixes and winding song structures and
overall very large album experience all
of that is back in a big way plus the
band is really going full throttle on
the death metal style vocals and the
synthesizers which give a lot of these
tracks an eerie and wintery vibe the
synths on the intro frost take more of a
minimal approach providing a light and
chilly drone that sits on top of the
crunchy and ever-changing layers of
drums and guitars that hang below not
really changing up kralis's
tried-and-true formula and sound but
it's there it's providing something it's
an element the pummeling performance and
production on this track is really the
driver of this song and that's okay it's
a very visceral and unforgiving
beginning to this lp but it does hit a
few lulls in its 10 minute run time and
in comparison with everything else here
it's actually one of the weaker moments
on the lp even if it is pretty good
which is another way of saying
everything gets more exciting and
intriguing from here as the synths begin
to take a bigger role on these tracks
and the riffs and rhythms that are
presented evolve faster and faster the
synths on the song telos provide some
pretty icy lead melodies eventually
giving way to some of the most twisted
and discordant guitar passages i've
heard since like the last gore guts
record the track is four minutes long
but each section hits with a pretty
great amount of contrast with the last
leg introducing these uh very airy cords
that kind of envelop the band's guitars
and drums heathen swill is absolutely
relentless with some of the most
muscular drums and riffs on the whole
project really the drumming on this
track is a total workout and creates an
almost hypnotic sensation for the six
minutes it lasts which is really
enhanced by the ethereal synth leads and
these spiraling riffs that you can
really get lost in the arch lights intro
has a similar effect too eventually the
track breaks down into these slower bits
that feature some of the most mysterious
melodic interplay between the synths and
guitars too dismal entity kicks off with
these insanely complex and off-kilter
galloping rhythms there's a variety of
synth patches on the track too huge
horns spectral bells a short and sweet
ambient interlude too which goes over
better than some of the stuff the band
was toying with on gobi forgotten then
finally we have the massive title track
which lasts 14 minutes and is really an
edge of your seat listen uh or at least
it should be if you've been compelled by
and you've withstood everything that has
been hitting you up until this point
from the gorgeous and evocative
progressive synth passages at the start
of the track eventually leading to this
slow build of black metal guitars and
drums that just gets thicker and thicker
and heavier and heavier as it moves
along reaching this epic fiery immersive
wall of sound yeah it's a great ending
to the project and overall i think this
uh really sounds like a new chapter for
krallus at the moment the synths really
have added a lot of color and dynamics
to their already really great sound and
yet it sounds like they're just starting
to scratch the surface of what's
possible with this slightly different
direction here i think this thing's a
great record really krause's best in
years feeling a light to decent eight on
this one tran position have you given
this album a listen did you love it did
you hate it what would you rate it
you're the best you're the best what
should i review next hit the like if you
like please subscribe and please don't
cry hit the bell as well over here next
to my head is a video that you could
check out in a dog barking uh yeah yeah
that's that's what's there anthony
fantano kralis
oh forever
